# Problem 7 {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-note icon=false} ## Problem

By listing the first six prime numbers: $2, 3, 5, 7, 11$, and $13$, we can see that the $6$th prime is $13$.

What is the $10\,001$st prime number?

::: ### Julia ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.julia .cell-code} is_divisible_by(n::Integer, q::Integer) = n % q == 0; function find_next_prime(primes) n = primes[end] while true n += 2 not_prime = false for q ∈ primes not_prime = is_divisible_by(n, q) if not_prime break end end if not_prime continue end return(n) end end; function find_n_primes(n::Integer) primes = [2, 3] while length(primes) < n next_prime = find_next_prime(primes) push!(primes, next_prime) end return primes end; p7() = find_n_primes(10_001)[end]; p7() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ``` 104743 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.julia .cell-code} using BenchmarkTools; @benchmark p7() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=3} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html}
